titleInfo.title: James S. Tippett photo album: Peabody Demonstration School, circa 1922

location.physicalLocation: Metropolitan Nashville/Davidson County Archives, Nashville Public Library

mods.abstract: An album of photographs of Peabody Demonstration School inscribed to James S. Tippett (1885-1958), a distinguished writer and educator who was the Director at the school from 1918-22. The album photos are: 1) Demonstration School; 2) Social Religious Buildings; 3) Industrial Arts Building; 4) Office Building; 5) View of Campus; 6) Library; 7) City Champs, ’21-’22, picturing female student athletes; 8) Ward-Belmont 16th Avenue; 9) Hermitage-Jackson’s Home; and 10) Garden Hermitage. Tippett left the school to join the Lincoln School at Teachers College in N.Y., as an instructor and special investigator. He began to write books for children, as well as short stories, poems, and essays on education during his career. In 1972 his name was added to the North Carolina Educational Hall of Fame. Historically, the Peabody Demonstration School was established in 1915 on the George Peabody School for Teachers’ campus, and had its origins in the Winthrop Model School, the first southern school for demonstrating teaching methods. Winthrop was founded in 1892 on the University of Nashville campus by the Peabody Board of Trustees. The Peabody Demonstration School was closed in 1974, and a group of parents, alumni, students and teachers formed the University School of Nashville. The school now occupies seven acres across from Vanderbilt University. Forms part of James S. Tippett photo album, Peabody Demonstration School. 1 photo album w b & w photos.

titleInfo.title: James S. Tippett photo album, Peabody Demonstration School.
